1124013550777917440.text:
15/ One other point to consider is that old data on compensation showing much less steep curves (or Euro data) is super misleading because of the way taxes and perqs worked/work.

Even if comp looks the same, there was/is massive inequality in other dimensions.

1124013549083348999.text: 14/ I am not advocating either way. But the discussion and comparisons in the article are weak imho. The real culprit in all of this is how to build a compensation model for a company and that is something needing to be re-thought but solutions are exceedingly difficult.

1124013547313352705.text: 13/ A weird thing also seen is in local economies when big employers make changes like this is that at the micro level, prices go up for big purchases. This was something we saw in the Seattle area with one-time changes to comp as well (or supply drops for housing/cars/schools).

1124013545329393664.text:
12/ But social science theory says that sort of amount gets noticed once (as a one time bonus) but then down the line no one notices and the “problem” resurfaces.

To address for the 80% of non-managers could takes billions of dollars. And still only noticed once.

1124013543278481410.text: 11/ As this whole curve is so steep, it is worth thinking about how this plays out at each level from most senior. The dollars to spread get smaller and the number of people to spread to goes up.

1124013541240000512.text:
10/ If you have 100 “VP” titles in a big company, you can pay them all 1M/yr for 100M. But if you take that 100M and instead spread half (50% pay cut) across 15,000 front line managers then they each get maybe $3000/yr more.

That’s def a lot (likely an extra paycheck).

1124013538849304576.text:
9/ Second, it costs a lot of money. A lot. And then starts to look like “peanut butter” from a comp perspective and won’t “influence” or “incent” (another topic).

Other than banking (!), very high total pay costs generally result in CEO changes and restructurings.

1124013535229616129.text:
8/ Yet evening this out is much more difficult than it looks. First there’s the obvious problem in a free market. The big companies that pay less to senior people will soon have none. 

There are only a few places where being mission driven has been tried but isn’t sustainable.

1124013533199589377.text:
7/ This is much more “real” and “visible” than CEO pay. People see the steepness between individual, senior, director, senior director. 

And given the numbers of employees there’s a clearly visible performance/contribution curve that isn’t being “enforced”.

1124013530489995264.text:
6/ This is easy to see — everyone sees the comp difference in the “ladder levels” at their company and they see the rarified air. 

But they also see the frustrations in “really is this person doing *that* much more than the person doing the work?”

1124013528489312258.text:
5/ If you take as a given that fixing the CEO is super difficult (and worth having some, a little, empathy for how hard it is to hold the job) then the core issue is that pay is structured at a nearly exponential curve.

Pay scales look more like prize money at a golf tournament.

1124013526459342854.text: 4/ The focus on CEOs is obvious but I think the real focus should be on how companies structure the compensation curve or waterfall. This is something I always struggled with and really pushed on because it is where the true anomalies occur.

1123432078593236993.text: Wow things have changed since I was there :-)https://twitter.com/juliankoh/status/1123334738608099328 …

1123310841670000640.text: 20/ Customers are still making choices that take a couple of years to make and last for decades. They will never stop wanting openness. Competitors will never stop claiming openness. Leaders leading will continue to appear not open. Cycle of enterprise software. // END

1123310840822681600.text: 19/ It might seem cynical but in practice this is just rooted in engineering. One experience I went through (only in part) was the Office file format standardization. Read about Open XML for some history as it is instructive. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_Open_XML …

1123310840113799168.text: 18/ Being open is much easier when you're racing to replace an incumbent. Chances are if you win, in some period of time you will become the entrenched leader being asked to be open in exactly the ways that are difficult for you.

1123310839400882176.text: 17/ But remember this also gets back to the history of how things were made and what got them there in the first place. The points of openness being "demanded" are literally the innovations that the vendor made to get them to leadership.

1123310838738112513.text: 16/ The environment becomes somewhat cynical at this point because commitments are made, deadlines missed, and expectations not met. It is easy to interpret this as the leading vendor dragging feet and holding on.

1123310838050222080.text: 15/ It is during this time that dissatisfaction with the existing leader reaches a peak level. The pressure mounts for the existing leader to join the consortium of 2-n vendors.

1123310837312057344.text: 14/ Caught in the middle of all of this are enterprise customers that are trying to keep systems running but more than that they want to move forward, add new capabilities, and continue to avoid being locked in or pay too much.

1123310836548661249.text: 13/ Almost always then, there becomes some alignment among the numbers 2 through n competitors (some old or new) around a new open "standard"--the "anybody but X" approach. We've seen this with APIs on Unix, database APIs, browsers. Usually such organizations start with "Open".

1123310835751739392.text: 12/ For example, old on-prem systems provided direct SQL access to data. SaaS cloud systems do this through APIs, but these APIs do not allow for many of the same techniques that old systems did. But they are open, just differently.

1123310834942222336.text: 11/ If the market leader doesn't espouse openness it is often not simply resisting openness, but because opening up along the lines of the new entrant is technically difficult. That is literally because new entries do things in new ways.

1123310834250276866.text: 10/ Many forget that Windows, which by some measures was considered extremely proprietary, was originally viewed as one of many open alternatives to having an open set of choices for "graphical environments". PS: Windows was always open.

1123310833587503104.text: 9/ When it comes to competing in market on openness, new entrants to an existing category almost always enter based on the fact that the winner was in some material way closed/proprietary/locked. Remember this is a cycle though, and how that winner got there was by being open.

1123310832748613632.text: 8/ If you define your product to require maintaining abstraction layers then you are only making it more difficult to compete with a new entrant that will abstract their solution differently to provide improved features, better scale, security, performance, etc.

1123310832023007232.text: 7/ (2) is controversial but something I believe: Every interesting innovation comes from breaking the carefully crafted abstraction layers that exist in a v1 architecture/product.

1123310831276478464.text: 6/ (1) this just makes acquiring capabilities easier as any vendor is motivated to include more stuff, even if not best of breed--this is the rise of the enterprise bundle (2) everyone knows as a practical matter that abstraction layers/interfaces can't last forever.

1123310830529859584.text: 5/ These are many ways to comfort customers during their decision making process. BUT also going on during decision making is reality of Ent CIOs wanting to simplify their infrastructure and have as few vendors as possible. Right or wrong, that is a strategy.

1123310829758058498.text: 4/ All of these conspire to "mandate" (to the degree possible) vendors be open and support any number of potential exit strategies too numerous to mention: open APIs, data export, extensibility/customization, plugins/providers, and of course OSS itself.

1123310829053435904.text: 3/ That's why a driving concern is "lock-in" or the worry that an Ent will lose control of their own infrastructure because vendors sell products that do some combination of: fail to innovate, raise prices, don't integrate, break compat.

1123310828365598720.text:
2/ Running enterprise software at scale is enormously difficult and expensive. Decisions made one year last for 20 years. Yet decisions must be made.

We should not forget how openness is so much different for an entire enterprise infra than for one tech enthusiast on their own.

1123310827245789184.text: 1/ Competing in enterprise often turns into a battle over "standards" or "openness" yet things play out much differently than people expect. Thoughts on competing with standards and the open-proprietary cycle of enterprise products...pic.twitter.com/ld7QhviVMZ

1122199418000658433.text: 13/ Video was super fun to make (ty @withfries2). Others who worked on it back then are here on twitter hoping they will join in. This is decidedly how things rolled from my own unrehearsed perspective, not history—25 yrs is a long time & Rashomon is real. ENJOY! // END

1122199416914366464.text: 12/ Still others thought game over, Office's to lose. Thus the choice to take on massive risk in a feature like Clip-It should not be under-estimated. I love this part of that era of MS. Taking risk as a leader, regardless of how secure, is a truly differentiated part of culture.

1122199415890907136.text: 11/ The makers of those products were also working on but late with Windows products. The industry was still in a mode that assumed when those products arrived, the ones that had always been second place from Microsoft would be back in 2nd place.

1122199414758469632.text: 10/ Many might see Office through the lens of always being the leader. In 1994 Office was just almost the leader on Windows but Windows was still very new and *just* becoming corporate (debate over GUI still raging) and the true unit leaders were MS-DOS 1-2-3 and WordPerfect.

1122199413722476544.text: 9/ In the video we talk about the path that got us to super high tech combined with super fun—it all fits together now. We knew all the constraints but were so focused on trying to solve the problem we were willing to risk not solving the "whole" problem.

1122199412682317825.text: 8/ (2) the low-risk solution was to offer more "Help" through books or Microsoft approved courses (eg "Microsoft University" was a thing). Scaling that would cost money and be tough but also seemed so old school. There had to be a technology answer.

1122199411608526848.text: 7/ So when thinking about Clippy, it is always worth remembering the complexity of the product. It wasn't about being a cute "gimmick" but was about trying to achieve a breakthrough on what remains an enormously complex task with few peers.

1122199410564161536.text: 6/ Clippy was created out of necessity. Every competitor had features but people could not use them. Books, in-person courses, even college credit were the norm for learning how to use Office. But this wasn't sustainable as a business as the product hoped to grow.

1122199409595281410.text: 5/ With thousands of "commands" available at any time (3500 in 1997), it is one of the hardest design problems, yet solving this is required because Office customers are *everyone*. Office remains one of the most sophisticated tools used by the masses. Crazy to think about.

1122199408567676928.text: 4/ (1) In the 90's software was really hard to use. Many products are difficult for normal people to use difficult like AutoCAD, Photoshop are but those are tools that are a profession. Office is the tool for every profession used in addition to highly skilled tools.

1122199407540051969.text: 3/ Two things for twitter but watch the video. (1) Features aren't designed in a vacuum. (2) Risk-taking is a huge part of product design and what risk means is highly contextual as well. Easy to get caught up in cute/dumb, but the context is what makes this interesting and fun.

1122199404536942592.text: 2/ As they say, there's some "never-before-seen footage" that should bring a smile to any maker. But really this video is about a journey through problem solving and design aka product management. Was Clippy a failure? Why be so dumb? How did THAT happen?pic.twitter.com/ENiliD7ChH

1121639383835107330.text: 24/ Anyway this is one set of observations over why email is so difficult which is why there is a constant desire to build a better experience. I mostly wanted to try to gain some empathy for what goes on when making one. Like everything, it is way easier from the outside. // END

1121639383017242633.text: 23/ The sum of these makes for a big client. That gets us back to the challenge email platform providers have. Not only do they have this same input for clients they want to differentiate backend platforms too. So the debate over "where should the code for X go" is perennial.

1121639382228668416.text: 22/ The neat thing about email clients is they have a gravity like a black hole--each person has their own thing they want to put into email because they have to use email...plus just one other thing. Notetaking, reading list, brainstorming, collaboration, messaging, etc.

1121639381347917824.text: 21/ New clients can be vastly better when the usage pattern aligns with how a given person wishes to use mail (eg composition, transaction, searching, calendaring, task mgmt). The design challenge across modalities and client platforms remain.

1121639380513202181.text: 20/ Alternative email clients (alternatives to the platform's) are always super interesting because they bring a new perspective much the same way a new platform creates a new perspective.

1121639379766611968.text: 19/ Then comes mobile which was awful for big email platforms because all their features went away, hidden behind the most basic of mail protocols. And crazy stuff like weird IMAP folders or "local" POP3 folders. iPhone special casing proprietary gmail then Exchange was *huge*.

1121639378814586881.text:
18/ Gmail thought of contacts as almost an afterthought. You either typed an address the first time or gmail would remember (or you could search) for an address. Forget trying to import a CSV and get any schema to work.

Also as an aside, threads were another huge difference.

1121639377958866944.text: 17/ Contacts were an interesting split too. Outlook started from the notion that you had a personal address book (a total PC era thing) and Corp directory. Like folders you carefully curated an addressbook (also a cache too that became increasingly important and problematic).

1121639377036136448.text: 16/ Thus gmail was optimized for transactions. The "archive" feature seemed crazy to Outlook people until you think excellent search and thus was born inbox 0. Also viewing email as transactional meant email creation was secondary so who needs tables. And Firefox did spelling.

1121639376272805891.text: 15/ For those that had been sentenced to Outlook and suffering with 10000 messages because they didn't have the patience for folders, having fantastic search made the whole experience much much improved. (btw, pilers logic doesn't work for Drive but I digress).

1121639375350067201.text: 15/ Gmail came along and had a whole different set of assumptions. No surprise but coming from a search company AND seeing that search wasn't working anywhere (it also didn't work on POP3 mail) and folders don't work across clients..so the default was "pilers".

1121639374620205057.text: 14/ Coming from Office, Outlook was also highly optimized for email creation. We even moved the whole text engine of Word to Outlook to bring the richness of Word (which by then supported HTML) to create super fancy email with columns, tables, glossary, autocorrect, spelling,...

1121639373827522561.text: 13/ This led to Outlook observing: there are "filers" and "pilers". It wasn't uncommon to see pilers w/10,000 inbox items. Search was slow but it didn't matter because logically(!) people would sort by date, sender, or subject to find things. There were no compressed threads yet.

1121639372984504321.text:
12/ But folders are "confusing" so Outlook 97 hid them. 

Search was less important just like there wasn't full text search in a library vertical file. The folder told you what was in it. But of course as we know now on desktop PCs most files are on the desktop and not filed.

1121639372065894400.text: 11/ So reading a message meant reply then file, or just file (or delete but no one deleted). If you were to look at Outlook folder views you would see tens or hundreds of folders. One reviewer had a folder for every tech company and subfolder for each person in that company.

1121639371193499648.text:
10/ Every generation likes to think they get way more mail than predecessors (they also only had the letter 'O' and no '0').

Outlook (and Exchange) built heavily on the folder metaphor. The architectural assumption was that people would file email messages like memos or...files.

1121639370421702656.text:
9/ (wow that was a painful but, painfully true, re-read and there were worse--try reading the word "Byzantine  in a review !) 

As an example challenge consider the transactional approach to email--that is dealing with the inbox and trying to get to zero.

1121639368903380992.text: 8/ Invariably this leads to platforms building feature laden experiences--extremely difficult to design, build across client platforms, and even learn. Outlook became dominant client because of features and rise of corporate email. But look at the first review from @waltmossbergpic.twitter.com/b08Aqa5Eq7

1121639368089722880.text: 7/ Then take all of this and make it work the same potentially across a desktop apps, browser, and mobile (across iOS and android) AND integrate mail, contact, calendaring, delegates, resources, potentially tasks. And have extensibility (add-ins) across those.

1121639367330582528.text: 6/ The way mail platform makers try to address this includes building features on top of the protocol that are manifest in the client (eg the wrong place) not in the protocol: search, labels, flags, favorites, right mgmt, even folder semantics.

1121639365778628608.text: 5/ Having one user interface accomodate all of these not just in one app, but switching between them at any one time, and the underlying features work at any given time is crazy difficult. Do you know how many debates we had over this 20 yrs ago:pic.twitter.com/dUqJflOEkP

1121639364964966407.text:
4/ Email is unlike any other end-user tool in number of distinct modalities present at any time. It is a:

* transaction engine (read & clear)
* filing cabinet
* search engine
* writing tool

Any of those are basic. Plus semantically it's "to do" "follow up" "share" "crm"....

1121639364184821761.text: 3/ Most everything in email that is interesting to do implies being tied to the primary client of the email platform you use, *even* though the basic protocol/format is a standard. If you think email is hard this way, try scheduling.

1121639363253719040.text: 2/ First, important to keep in mind that the protocols and overall architecture (to/from, message body) are outside the control of an email program. That's kind of weird--the fundamental interaction surface is a least common denominator.

1120381713685700608.text:
12/ Other dark patterns in the post (and referenced book) are simply dark. Being tricky, intentionally hard to discover, or just illogical on purpose are all signs of an immature product development process. 

Please take this to heart and think about measures of success. // END

1120381712289034240.text:
11/ For decades we measured success in MS Office by taking less time to do tasks —> productivity. Ppl have better things to do than s/w.

Enterprise SaaS seems to intrinsically drive a desire for engagement (“delivering value”), which seems disconnected from productivity.

1120381710992941056.text: 10/ Simply measuring engagement for any product independent of a user’s goal in using the product is a choice, but increasing might be a long term problem.

1120381709726277632.text: 9/ Shopping is a great example as well. Understanding the intent of the customer for landing at the site is critical—is this a search for a product or a transaction? Choosing wrong can be frustrating and choosing requires some way of understanding intent.

1120381708421844992.text: 8/ Similarly, enterprise s/w wants customers to use new features but doing so interrupts the users understood flow and thus drives decreases in productivity.

1120381707180339200.text:
7/ Posting a message to a social network is an interesting case of where design keeps adding more and increasing friction. 

I suspect these designs are a constant struggle since more posts are better, but richer posts yield more engagement.

1120381705896882176.text:
6/ But generally, the perception is:

Consumer s/w (networks, commerce, etc.), when done well, tilts towards encouraging you to use a product more regardless of your intent.

Enterprise software, when done well, is about being transactional and encouraging productivity.

1120381704613404672.text: 5/ Enterprise has flows that are experiential. For example, finding the right template for a presentation or figuring out the right chart to present data. These are immersive experiences that are similar to browsing in a consumer app.

1120381703342575616.text: 4/ There are interesting modalities to consider. For example, consumer apps always optimize the heck out of the flow to get people signed up or to complete a purchase. So clearly there are flows where the design language is “optimize a transaction”.

1120381701962620929.text:
3/ Often the discussion tends to be “consumer is different” and in consumer there is a drive for engagement from design.

When discussing enterprise, most of the time the discussion is “yeah people *have* to sit in front of tools all day”.

1120381700574285824.text: 2/ One dark pattern can be engagement. Something I believe, that is not broadly shared, is that the divergence between customers (“users”) and product design over engagement is more subtle and nuanced than usually described (when I debate this topic).

1120381698812698624.text: “Weaponized Design: Dark Patterns in UX” by Filip Wilczek // IMO this describes a most fundamental design challenge when designing for engagement—is using your product more or in a particular manner aligned with the goals of your user? https://link.medium.com/GxLhyhqf6V   1/

1118417466449747968.text: 12/ No matter what, someone somewhere was always saying the bad thing would happen. And when the good things happen, well we know everyone claims they were saying it would happen (let me check my sent mail…). BigCo Life  // END

1118417465594138627.text: 11/ A company might be totally messed up. Everything might be a train wreck. The presence of chair throwing though is not why that is the case. And that’s because that chair throwing was there during all the positives as well.

1118417465023688706.text: 10/ Stories about chair throwing are fun to read. BigCo are dysfunctional by definition simply because at any given moment some non-zero set of people believe everything is totally messed up, and they might very well be.

1118417464272887808.text: 9/ There’s a moment of “oh wow, I guess that didn’t matter all that much” or “geez, I thought we were geniuses but that good thing would have happened anyway” or “yikes, we were totally debating the wrong thing”.

1118417463517954048.text: 8/ Personally I’ve lived through exceedingly good times and horribly bad times, and the reality is that they looked and felt exactly the same. I often have to remind myself of the outcome of something when friends look back and we think about all the chair throwing.

1118417462876205056.text: 7/ People doing the work just want to do good work and not be hit by a chair. They see that the dots aren't connecting but all that chair throwing is scary, if they are paying attention to it, or random if they have work to do.

1118417462121250816.text: 6/ When you’re in a big company, you know the boss doesn’t know the details of how something works or all the implications of changing it on a whim. People in the middle are just trying to keep the wheels on the bus and importantly not get run over by it.

1118417461399789568.text: 5/ What makes a big company big, is that it has the time, resources, and structure to debate, ruminate, consider a zillion points of view for anything. People all up and down the org opine about decisions and email is the great “flattener” of org charts, time, space.

1118417460724559872.text: 4/ Thing thing is no matter what was happening, it was the same chair throwing. Decision-making in a large organization always amounts to “no matter what happens someone always said it would.”  Chair throwing is just people saying something won’t work, with emphasis.

1118417459982135296.text: 3/ When things are not going well, stringing together any set of chair throwing points looks like, well, chair throwing. It looks like infighting, juvenile, power plays. Connecting chair throwing incidents makes the whole company look like clown town.

1118417459151642630.text: 2/ When things are going well (financially, customers, etc), stringing together any set of chair throwing points can look like a mastermind of a strategy. There was a battle, clearer heads prevailed, and then a strong decision was made. #leadership #strategy #execution

1118417458145009664.text:
1/ Some thoughts on big companies about something I believe.

Nearly everything that happens in a big company happens with a battle, dissent, even name calling—the very best and worst with no correlation between the volume of (let’s call it) chair throwing and quality of outcome.pic.twitter.com/c51hC9C0lQ

1112101761295093761.text:
21/ I wrote about the business reasons/differences and more the general topic of pre-announcements. Please check it out for more. 

“Pre-Announcing as a Strategy”https://link.medium.com/eon6dC0kuV

1112101760452063232.text:
20/ Personal Story: Windows and Office had very different ways of announcing. 

Many thought Office would never tell the market what was going on while Windows was always open and transparent.

Turns out that is true but there were business reasons for that.

1112101759713894400.text: 19/ The idea that pre-announcing can cause competitors to mess up or cause a non-existent product to freeze the market somehow is truly a unicorn thing. Founders are almost never chasing a bigCo directly and so such announcements are noise.

1112101758711398401.text:
18/ Vaporware. This is the announcement of something that never makes it to market because the product was never on a path to complete (too buggy, to fragile, sucky, etc.) 

Many ascribe this to evil market manipulation. It is mostly incompetence.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaporware

1112101757943873536.text:
17/ Tech industry still have a bit of collective memory over two aspects of pre-announcing that come up when something is announced a fails to deliver.

Osborne effect. This is a pre-announce that tanks your existing business. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osborne_effect …

1112101757004308480.text: • Signal a whole new business or expand view of Co. Sometimes a significant pivot or transformative product in a company will take time to execute but you need to begin a longer/longish process of laying the groundwork in a playful manner. This subsumed all other reasons too.

1112101756131901440.text: • Customers demand lead-time. In enterprise software or for big (or seasonal) purchases Cu want to have time to absorb, understand, plan. CIOs run their own planning and budgets and surprises sound cool but don’t fit within this and thus missed opportunities. IBM mastered this.

1112101755288838144.text: • Sales, support, distribution. For physical goods it takes time to execute on mfg and supply chain logistics and get to store shelves or stockrooms—specially true to “noisy” times of year like holiday and back to school. Preannounce garners attention and support in channel.

1112101754424840192.text: • Marshaling partners/ecosystem. Many products are acquired as part of a network of supporting products operating distinctly. Pre-announcements give partners to plan and execute for one big moment of availability. An example: subscription content :-)

1112101753556602880.text:
12/ These above are all reasons why a Co might want to pre-announce but these all have an element of choice or decision.

In many biz pre-announce is required and is part of the way business needs to get done. Here are four reasons pre-announcements are a legit biz strategy need.

1112101752717729797.text: • Leak. Sometimes word leaks out and the product under development develops a life of its own. Unable to contain or own the messaging a pre-announce happens. In enterprise this becomes important to continue to maintain credibility with customers.

1112101751652380672.text: • Big Event. Most would be amazed how many pre-announcements are created because of a big 1st party conference or headline keynote. My view is that the vast amount of pre-announced “stuff” happens because the company feels somewhat exposed on a big stage.

1112101750989717504.text: • PR. Who doesn’t love a good viral PR campaign for a  product still under development? Sometimes announcements are just about PR. You can often spot these because they are arm’s length and have few details to support. It feels one-off.

1112101750142468096.text: • Rounding out an offering. Sometimes a whole product is in market or announced but it is still incomplete in some adjacency or feature (a connector, accessory, etc.) Pre-announcing this adjacency is a way to round out the product. AirPower was that maybe?

1112101749353934848.text: • Competitive. Might be neck and neck with a competitor that announces or is rumored to announce something. A pre-announce strategy can draw attention to your efforts that the market might not know about. This way you’re not viewed as behind. Example: Windows touch before iPad.

1112101748175339520.text: • Early announcement, but not finished. Sometimes announcements seem like “pre” but are really on a schedule that is before a product is done or available in channel. It might seem like a pre-announce but the maker has a plan.

1112101747344838656.text:
5/ For many products, holding off on any/all information seems like a way to maximize bang for the buck so to speak. That’s a specific strategy but not always appropriate.

Why might pre-announcing be part of a biz/product strategy? Here are six reasons, not always good but…

1112101746694713344.text: 4/ So while Apple missed a product it’s only nostalgia that prevents us from remembering that process of launching and announcing with success has not always been. In fact it is so unreliable that announcing is often disconnected from delivery. With that comes strategic intent.

1112101745956515841.text:
3/ Apple has come to define best in class in tech products for captivating and surprise launch announcements with near instant availability.

It wasn’t always this way for Apple. In early says of Jobs as CEO Apple famously botched availability. Tim Cook fixed the whole pipeline.

1112101744555646976.text:
2/ Between today’s world of SaaS with its constant delivery of “value” and sneaky, cool, viral adoption of consumer tech, we might have collectively lost sight of value of product launches. 

A launch is a unique moment when customers go from zero knowledge to ownership.

1112101743695785984.text:
1/ Pre-announcing a product (/feature) seems really dumb. Still, anything that happens so often probably has a strategic or even clever use.

1106289019971788800.text: 25/ Did we stop and change to a different business? We did not.15+ years later and people now ask "why didn't MS go further". Hopefully this thread gives you an idea of how it feels to push and pivot 100's B of market cap in a world where all eyes are on you.

1106288744343076864.text: 24/ Every time we had a bug in some old code (IE 6 anyone) or a mistake in how we executed we would take a step backwards with some stakeholder. People would say "see we told you". But you keep going because the truth is this was an existential challenge for the company.

1106288743688765440.text: 23/ We had to bring stakeholders along with us on the journey. Imagine all the changes internally had to take place across a vast billion-node ecosystem of PCs and the long tail of those that contribute to that.

1106288742988300288.text: 22/ MSFT released Windows XP SP2. Then a new Office. Then updated .NET. Then began to train customers. Then joined the security community. And so on. One step at a time internally and across stakeholders.

1106288742266867714.text: 21/ All you can do as an organization executing on this sort of pivot is to do the work. Keep people informed. Build incremental trust across all stakeholders by actions.

1106288741616746496.text: 20/ Our messages match our actions but only if a stakeholder is willing to believe our long term goal. But that meant we had to earn trust--the very thing we didn't have.

1106288740975017984.text: 19/ All through this we are changing. We are become secure by design, by default, by development. But it takes time. All of this chaos is happening while we are trying to do this.

1106288740392005634.text: 18/ Enterprise account teams who sold customers on "solutions" using extensibility in Office/Windows found those solutions broken. Literally companies could not close the books, our customers had customer service problems, and more. We broke tens of millions of PCs.

1106288739603701760.text: 17/ Test managers who believed they were the final go/no-go for a product to release to customers were now just another check along the way. Even making a CD or code for download was some outside force.

1106288738840133632.text: 16/ Managers who had defined processes for a team now had to turn over leadership of a key new corporate pillar to a newly formed team. No matter what your dev process every engineer had to go through SD3 training.

1106288738068422656.text: 15/ People who had contributed a ton in one dimension suddenly found that dimension less key. At MS there were tons of teams that released code for customers all the time. Now we needed to control that--imagine you can't go "solve customer problems".

1106288737422458881.text: 14/ Internally there was massive chaos. Why? Because in any organization inverting priorities means that established norms for leadership, teams, rewards, and more are also inverted.

1106288736784928769.text: 13/ No matter what we did the external view was that we were doing these things not to "pivot to security" but to use security as air cover to secure our business.

1106288736126435328.text:
12/ Signing device drivers. Clearly that was a way to make sure that MS exerted a new level of control over OEMs.  

Favoring signed executables? Obviously a plot against competitors. Imagine a world where code isn't signed?

1106288735505670144.text: 11/ Blocking attachments and file types in Outlook but not Office docs (we had put the security controls in the apps, third parties had not) was obviously a plot to secure Office.

1106288734842941441.text:
10/ Making it hard to download software from the internet was obviously a plot to favor Internet Explorer over any browser you might download.

Breaking Antivirus in Windows (making it more secure) really a plot to favor MS AV.

1106288734201237504.text: 9/ Then there were actual actions. Most everything we did for TwC viewed through that context was believed to be part of a grand plot to further cement existing leadership. Examples:

1106288733500788736.text: 8/ Imagine the irony of "Microsoft" (scare quotes) writing a memo about being trustworthy in 2002. This was literally peak "anti-trust" (see what I did there). Everything was believed to have ulterior motives. Dotcom bubbled and only MSFT remained. Scary world.

1106288732770951168.text: 7A/ Quick 2002 history. A series viruses on  desktops and servers had crippled the world's  computing infrastructure. In one day, one virus estimated to cost 8-10 BILLION dollars in lost productivity. Retail stores missed xmas sales due to SQL injection. All MSFT. Sh*t was real.

1106288732112482304.text: 7/ Talked about MSFT's trustworthy computing. There are parallels to what FB is going through that I personally can't "unsee". Not just the need, but the action (about trust), and importantly the context.

1106288731466547200.text: 6/ Because the whole reason for the pivot is that things need to change. Why do things need to change? Because the company missed something? And for some period of time the company didn't change. Worse the company said "we got this" but really didn't.

1106288730774528000.text: 5/ The context of the time determines the immediate response from stakeholders. Skepticism and cynicism will dominate. This actually makes the whole thing even more stressful to execute. Why?

1106288730078244864.text: 4/ Pivots have to happen out in the open. You can't secretly do one and then spring it on all those stakeholders. In a sense it turns things into a bit of a reality show, which is unfortunate.

1106288729289744384.text: 3/ What is going on is that all the stakeholders (internal, press, analysts, investors, pundits, users, and customers) are racing to get to the "end" or "conclusion" of the pivot. But you are just starting.

1106288728446664704.text: 2/ Pivot might not be the right word but it is how it feels. One day you're whole org is optimized to get something done that has been successful and the next day you are literally doing the opposite. You're brain knows this. But it takes time--and some chaos.

1106288727758766081.text: 1/ Some thoughts on FB pivot and what it feels like to go through something like it. It is not a pivot in the ordinary sense. While existential in nature (like a startup pivot) the existing world also continues. Culture change is crazy difficult, for all.https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2019/03/a-note-from-mark-zuckerberg/ …

1105555977133121536.text: “Peak California” by @byrneseyeview // if you believe in a highly selective view of the past (funding history, cost to start a company, rent etc) and a selective read on the present too then this is good post.https://link.medium.com/03wSMWgm0U

1105548989678510080.text: BigTechCo 3 - Mullet Businesses by ⁦@sriramk⁩ // relevant  https://sriramk.com/bigtechco-3-mullets …

1105546629904424960.text: 40/ This maybe should have been a post but this is more fun to do. Let’s see what else I can add? Maybe AMA? I know there’s more.

1105546628746735616.text: 39/ One last thought. I’ve always believed in karma in all of this. If a company believes in freedom to innovate and free markets it should be out there defending those that are innovating, not being "helpful" to regulators to slow competition.

1105546627593330689.text: 38/ If you don’t believe large organizations themselves and on their own can be the biggest obstacles, then it is worth at least looking at state of the government dealing with major issues.

1105546626506985473.text: 37/ Success is by far the best regulatory structure in place. Success leads to poor optics on market situations and solution spaces that seem more like "master plans" that can’t work than truly genius strategic moves.

1105546625257111552.text: 36/ Every strength eventually becomes a weakness. That is what is unique about technology. The absence of physical barriers and presence of networks mean alternatives can change very quickly. But within a big company teh 4 P’s might as well be physical constraints.

1105546624082677760.text: 35/ Regulation, M&A or structural relief is "predicting" impacts in a dynamic market. If you’re going to do that then you have to think like a big company thinks, not think like how a big company would think if it was competitor or think like a really smart person w/o history.

1105546622895775744.text: 34/ Businesses are always made up of product, price, place, promotion. It is a failure of regulation to consider the interplay of all of these not just for how a company competes but how a company got to where it is and what that says for how they will decide stuff down the road.

1105546621670944768.text: 33/ Looking at what goes on with a new product in isolation of all other aspects of a business is how regulators arrive at "do something" but always those specific behaviors end up being weaknesses that will undo a product in market anyway. There’s so much evidence of this.

1105546620467273728.text: 32/ When building a new platform/industry there are many constraints. An existing big company is one (so are existing regulations etc). Creativity is applied across all of those. Android wasn’t just free code from google, but brought a whole bunch to mobile.

1105546619309584384.text: 31/ There are two kinds of innovations that surface when a big company has a mature/dominant position. Head-on and circumvent. Regretfully it is the head-on competition that gets all the attention but it won’t win because head-on isn’t a unique value proposition in the market.

1105546618210676736.text: 30/ The hardest thing for me about regulating tech is that actions always start from something a big company is doing strategically that seems wrong. The problem is these actions are almost always wrong for them as well, but you just can’t see it inside.

1105546617195642880.text: 29/ Of course MS was nowhere with phone and had been trying for years to build the Windows model (OEM licensing in particular). A core belief of having many phone models, royalty from many mfgs was always in the cards. So it was never going to be competitive.

1105546616004464641.text: 28/ But customers loved it the way customers loved alternatives to mainframes and new browsers. It was not head-on competition (eg a better blackberry than blackberry) but an entirely new value proposition, especially a year later w/App Store.

1105546614704238592.text: 27/ So the App Store, closed hardware, and more — all things in an IBM or MS context that would be viewed as problematic strategically—were implemented to create the iPhone. Which frankly was well-reviewed and also panned by many for many reasons.

1105546612447698944.text: 26/ This is all interesting because of the current vagueness of how to treat Apple. Apple’s core beliefs are rooted in all of these goings on in the industry. The iPhone literally developed to fix some of the industry’s long challenging problems from a uniquely apple perspective.

1105546078139572224.text: 25/ Just like IBM was genuinely worried that after market products would make mainframes perform poorly or worse (remember these things were enormously complex). So there were good and legit intentions to the constraints…that were misapplied.

1105546077082607617.text: 24/ Worth noting many people complain about crapware, spyware, malware, and other problems with new PCs. MS was actually trying to solve that. But then it probably wasn’t nice to lump competitive browser and media players in there. But wait—privacy, malware  in today’s context.

1105546073945174017.text: 23/ Regulators claimed victory but the loss already happened. But for none of the reasons the writers of history say at least IMHO. As a reminder, MS stopped working on IE 7 years before Chrome even existed—literally didn’t release a new version for 5+ years.

1105546070883393536.text: 22/ It was of course right to remedy the distribution of code, which was also counter to self-interest. Google, Chrome, etc. all achieved success before those were in effect. What? This isn’t regulation being too late, but had different value propositions customers valued.

1105546068580720640.text: 21/ So even when trying to compete in a new market the strategy was not going to work technically and customers would immediately know. Either they would ignore the key part of Windows or key part of x-platform. This is what a big company "master plan" looks like…ActiveDesktop.

1105546066273816576.text: 20/ Showing how much your own gravity as a big company can make even obvious steps strategically weak…MS knew browsers had to be cross platform so it built IE for Mac and Unix. Neat. BUT wait, the main strategic differentiator for IE was ActiveX which was clearly Windows only.

1105546061022560256.text: 19/ Imagine (some of us did) a world instead where MS would have built a browser that was an app distributed everywhere, running everywhere. That would have been a very different strategy. One that some imagined, but not when Windows was central.

1105546059877507072.text: 18/ That meant doing things like IBM did—finding holes in distribution where browsers could "sneak" in (OEM deals) and seeing how to make MS browser work best and only with Windows. Sound familiar? It does to me.

1105546058439053312.text: 17/ MS saw browsers as platform threat to Windows. Famously. Browsers though were an app—running everywhere, distributed everywhere. MS chose to compete as though browsing was on par with Windows (eg substitutes).

1105546057075712000.text: 16/ Biggest force in preventing market abuses are the strategies that brought success to a big company. Those are far more of a constraint than any regulation. This is not being "gummed up" or "constrained by lawyers" or anything. It is simply perspective. Success is crippling.

1105546055985188864.text: 15/ Story of IBM regulation is told as though PCs exist b/c of the case. That’s like saying ATT wireless exists b/c of the breakup. No one at ATT wanted wireless! They fought over landlines. Too many say regulation moves too slowly. I say it is companies that move too slowly.

1105546054747840512.text: 14/ I’ve heard people say IBM went into PCs because the AT loss caused them to look for growth or something. Ha. PCs were spun up because IBM was losing Minis. But everything about the PC was almost a fluke organizationally and strategically.

1105546053615403008.text: 13/ Imagine a world where IBM would have thought to do those on their own? Turns out IBM could not, but everyone else could including their own customers. The minicomputer was a direct threat not because of technology but because of those attributes.

1105546050054479872.text: 12/ IBM chose to prevent third parties from inter operating with mainframes sometimes at crazy levels (punch card formats). And then chose to defend until the end their business model of leasing.

1105546048716435456.text: 11/ Big companies defend their existing business in face of new competitors not by building better products, making customers like them more, or being creative. Too often they go down a path of trying to exploit the levers/knobs *they believe* are the key to success.

1105546047395225600.text: 10/ In the cases of technology innovators ultimately doing things that were found to be anti-competitive you can also find some pretty odd (or irresponsible depending on view) actions that were part of a "master plan" not to grow but to maintain/sustain the business advantage.

1105546045872697344.text: 9/ It is almost like natural forces of competition also have forces that prevent big companies successfully competing. This might not be true for natural resources or physical infrastructure (more shortly). But in anything where you vote with feet, device, dollars it seems to be.

1105546044576677888.text: 8/ Companies should be allowed to do that. And frankly what is so interesting and part of the story that is never told, actions big companies take against these "different in all respects" competitors are not all that helpful and end up being detrimental to their own world view.

1105546043326783489.text: 7/ Google and Microsoft were competitors but only by virtue of being tech companies hiring engineers. After that almost nothing about what was being made or sold was similar even if things could ultimately be viewed as substitutes.  That is literally the definition of innovation.

1105546042160766976.text: 6/ This gets all confused because both companies and Wall Street see "sectors" like tech, entertainment, retail and then assume new entrants will compete by the same model with what looks like the same product to some.

1105546040977977344.text: 5/ Every *potential* competitor is much more about how it impacts current business than about opportunity. Which is weird because the best competitors are not aiming for the existing business with the same value proposition or dollars (or customers).

1105546039879057408.text: 4/ By competitor I mean the entity most likely to be the reason for stumbling in the future. As companies grow the horizon for growth shrinks relative to the opportunity to mess up what is currently the wonderful business.

1105546038637522945.text: 3/ Most all I’ve experienced about Microsoft’s journey confirms what I now have come to understand is just how much big organizations are generally their own biggest competitor, and rarely is it the "obvious" competitor elsewhere.

1105546037396033536.text: 2/ I believe in regulation. I’ve worked before, during, after regulation. I’ve seen improper actions corrected and punished around the world. But I also believe that regulation can stifle other’s innovation when done too soon and cripple companies when punishment was the goal.

1105546034996899840.text: 1/ Antitrust success is a tale, like many, told by the victors. Usually, however, the only victors are the regulators and lawyers. Conflating/reversing cause/effect is the norm. When customers win, as they often do, the question worth asking is "why"?https://stratechery.com/2019/where-warrens-wrong/ …

1102326087017627648.text:

1102326085948043264.text: 5/ x-team technology bets. No project is a clean slate—there are always some underlying technology bets/approaches. Tools, platforms, frameworks, or deeper. Enumerate those up front. This too is a key cross-team point of coordination before project starts.

1102326084865945605.text: 4/ Schedule. How much time? This is very different than “how long”. This is the constraint for any work, not *the* work. The work is created by the team to fit within this constraint. Schedule is *the* key way multiple groups coordinate.

1102326083855167488.text: 3/ Resources. How many people does a project have to work with? Plan everything as though people on board and ramped up are how many to have. Don’t start a project assuming more people will show up soon (if they do, bonus or likely backfill, but not planned stuff).

1102326082743615488.text:
2/ Will riff from my POV on this. 

At scale the inputs (themselves a product of alignment/collab) are
• Resources
• Schedule
• x-team technology bets
• Scenarios or “themes”

Output is created/owned by the team (recursively) within those constraints.
